facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 398 of 1956 was filed in the Supreme Court.

facts.text: Appeal against Bombay High Court judgment dated March 19, 1956 in Appeal No. 45 of 1955.

facts.text: Arising from Bombay High Court judgment dated March 23, 1956 in Suit No. 468 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: 1955, arising out of the judgment and order dated March 23, 1956, of the said High Court in its Ordinary Original Civil. Jurisdiction in Suit No. 468 of 1951.

facts.text: Suit No. 468 of 1951 instituted by appellants (original plaintiffs) to recover Rs. 1,80,099-8-0 from respondents (original defendants).

anchor.surface_text: High Court in Suit No. 468 of 1951 instituted by the appellants  Original Plaintiffs  to recover from the respon- dents  Original Defendants  a sum of Rs. 1,80,099-8-0 with interest

facts.text: First appellant has been a member of East India Cotton Association Ltd. since 1932 as sole proprietor of Messrs. Narrondass Manordass (member firm).

anchor.surface_text: and decree passed by a single Judge of that High Court in Suit No. 468 of 1951 instituted by the appellants  Original Plaintiffs  to recover from the respon-

facts.text: Appellants carried on business in partnership as cotton merchants in name Messrs. Narrondass Manordass (partnership firm), second appellant.

anchor.surface_text: dents  Original Defendants  a sum of Rs. 1,80,099-8-0 with interest and companys. Since the year 1932 the first appellant has been a member of the East India

facts.text: Respondents are a partnership firm and member of the Association.

anchor.surface_text: Cotton Association Ltd.,  hereinafter referred to as the Association   as the sole proprietor of the firm of Messrs. Narrondass Manordass There in after referred

facts.text: Between September 23, 1947, and December 10, 1947, member firm sold 2,300 bales of Broach Vijay Fine 3/4 Navsari and/or Bardoli 7/8 Cotton to respondents for March-April 1948 delivery.

anchor.surface_text: Between September 23, 1947, and December 10, 1947, the member firm sold to the respondents 2,300 bales of Broach Vijay Fine 3/4 Navsari and or Bardoli 7/8 Cotton for March April 1948 Delivery.

facts.text: Out of 2,300 bales, 1,100 bales disposed of by Havalas, remaining 1,200 by cross-contracts, resulting in 700 bales outstanding for delivery.

anchor.surface_text: Out of these 2,300 bales, 1,100 bales were disposed of by means of Havalas and in respect of the remaining 1,200 bales, there were cross- compantracts. In the result when the time for Delivery arrived,

facts.text: Member firm failed to deliver 700 bales to respondents.

anchor.surface_text: sales in respect of 700 bales remained outstanding and the member firm was liable to give delivery of 700 bales to the respondents.

facts.text: Respondents Invoiced Back 700 bales on May 3, 1948, resulting in Rs. 1,07,530-8-0 due, total for all 2,300 bales Rs. 1,79,749-8-0 due from member firm.

anchor.surface_text: As however, the member firm failed to give delivery of the said 700 bales to the respondents, under the relevant by-laws of the Association, the respondents Invoiced Back these 700 bales to the member firm on May 3, 1948,

facts.text: Respondents sent eight separate Debit Notes and a consolidated debit note for Rs. 1,79,749-8-0.

anchor.surface_text: In respect of this sum of Rs. 1,79,749-8-0, the respondents sent to the member firm eight separate Debit Notes in respect of varying amounts and finally a companysolidated debit numbere for Rs. 1,79,749-8-0.

facts.text: Contract notes signed by Ramanlal Nagindas, salesman in Ready Cotton Department of partnership firm.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the compantract numberes in respect of these transactions had been signed by one Ramanlal Nagindas who had been employed as a salesman in the Ready Cotton Department of the partnership firm.

facts.text: Appellants contended Ramanlal had no authority to enter transactions or sign contracts, and contracts not in accordance with bylaws.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants compannted that the said Ramanlal Nagindas had numberauthority to enter into the said transactions or to sign compantract numberes in respect thereof on behalf of the appellants and also that the said compantracts were number

facts.text: Partnership firm paid Rs. 1,79,749-8-0 on May 7, 1948 without prejudice.

anchor.surface_text: The partnership firm, however, as the beneficiary under the said compantracts decided to pay the amounts claimed by the respon- dents without prejudice to the rights and companentions of both the parties. On May 7, 1948, the said sum of Rs. 1,79,748-8-0 was paid

facts.text: Further Rs. 350 penalty paid on June 6, 1948 without prejudice.

anchor.surface_text: A further sum of Rs. 350 being the amount of penalty for the alleged failure to tender the aforesaid 700 bales of the said compantracts of Broach Vijay March April 1948 Delivery, was also paid by the partnership firm to the respondents on June 6, 1948,

facts.text: Mr. Justice Shah held contracts void on August 20, 1950 in Petitions Nos. A/51, A/52, A/55, A/56 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Justice Shah delivered judgment in the said petitions on August 20, 1950, holding inter alia that the said compantracts were void as being number in accordance with the by- laws of the Association and allowed those petitions.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed SLPs against Shah J. judgment on or about April 6, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: These petitions were, however, dismissed by this Court on or about April 6, 1951.

facts.text: Appellants demanded return of Rs. 1,80,099-8-0 by letter dated May 2, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants thereafter by their attorneys letter dated May 2, 1951, called upon the respondents to return the said sum of I-Is. 1,80,099-8-0  being the aggregate of the said two sums of Rs. 1,79,749-8-0 and Rs. 350.

facts.text: Suit filed on May 7, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: with the result that on May 7, 1951, the appellants filed the suit against the respondents for repayment to them of the said sum with interest and companys.

facts.text: Appellants averred contracts void under Bombay Cotton Contracts Act, 1932 for omitting difference vs settlement rate (bylaws 139,141) and measurement (bylaw 80).

anchor.surface_text: In the plaint as filed the appellants averred that the said compantracts were void under the Bombay Cotton Contracts Act, 1932, as being number in accordance with the by-laws of the Association inter alia in the following respects  1  The compantract numberes produced by the respondents omitted to state the difference of Rs above or below the settlement rate of hedge compantracts for the purpose of periodical settlements as required by by-laws 139 and 141 and  2  numberprovision was made in any of the aforesaid compantract numberes with regard to the measurement of bales as required by the official form for delivery compantracts prescribed in bylaw 80.

facts.text: Respondents contended no bylaw required stating difference above/below settlement rate; provisions obsolete, no hedge contracts; bylaw 101 suspended since Nov 30, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents in their written statement compannted that there was numberby-law which required any person to agree upon any difference above or below the settlement rate of hedge compantracts for the purpose of periodical settlements and to state the same. They further compannted that the relative provisions companntained in the official compantract form had become obsolete as at all material times there were numberhedge compantracts bearing different numbers and in practice the said compantracts were number put through periodical settlements. They also compannted that at all material times there was numberby law which required any person to agree upon any specific measurements in respect of the bales agreed to be purchased inasmuch as the operation of by-law 101 in regard thereto had been suspended by the Board since November 30, 1942.

facts.text: Trial Judge (single Judge) held contracts void due to omission of difference term, no implied agreement, dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial Judge followed the judgment of Mr. Justice Shah and held that the omission of the clause regarding measurement in the compantract numberes did number alter the character or legal effect of the compantracts. He similarly held that the omission of any reference in the compantracts to the amount of difference above or below the settlement rate of hedge compantracts in the last term of the compantract numberes rendered the compantracts void. He however was of the opinion that there was numberimplied agreement between the parties of the nature alleged by the appellants and that the payment made by appellants to the respondents was voluntary and therefore dismissed the appellants suit with companys.

facts.text: Appellate High Court confirmed dismissal, held measurement omission irrelevant, no obligation for difference term, contracts valid.

anchor.surface_text: The appellate Court agreed with the learned trial Judge that the omission of the term regarding measurement in the compantract numberes did number affect the character or legal affect of the compantracts. In regard to the omission to fill-up the difference above or below the settlement rate fixed for the hedge compantracts in the last clause of the compantract numberes, however, the appellate Court was of the opinion that there was numberobligation on the parties to agree to add or deduct the difference above or below the settlement rate as compannted by the appellants.

facts.text: Supreme Court held contracts in accordance with bylaws, not void.

anchor.surface_text: The only question for our determination in this appeal is whether the compantracts between the parties were number in accordance with the by-laws of the Association and therefore void. ... we are of the opinion that the compantracts entered into between the appellant,-, and the respondents were number void as alleged.

facts.text: Board suspended operation of by-law 101 on November 30, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: The Board of Directors issued a numberice on November 30, 1942, suspending the operation of bylaw 101 as regards the measurement until further numberice.

facts.text: Delivery contracts not put through periodical settlements in practice.

anchor.surface_text: their companynsel stated before the Court that he did number wish to dispute the fact that delivery compantracts were at numbertime submitted to periodical settle- ments in the Association.

Section 8 1   Bombay Cotton Contracts Act, 1932  Save as hereinafter provided in this Act, any contract  whether either party thereto is a member of a recognized cotton association or not  which is entered into after the date on which this Act comes into operation and which is not in accordance with the by-laws of any recognized cotton association shall be void.

concepts.interpretation: Contracts are void only if not in accordance with by-laws; substantial compliance with prescribed form suffices, literal compliance not essential.

anchor.surface_text: By-law 101. Claims for excess measurement. In respect of all Forward Contracts, measurement shall approximate 13-1/2 tons per 50 bales provided that in respect of Forward Contracts, other than Hedge Contracts, the parties may agree upon any other measurement.

concepts.interpretation: Suspended by Board notice on Nov 30, 1942 regarding measurement; no need to mention measurement in contracts post-suspension.

anchor.surface_text: By-law 139. Settlement Days. All Delivery Contracts other than those excepted under By-laws 136 and Hedge Contracts shall be subject to periodical settlements through the Clearing House

concepts.interpretation: Requires periodical settlements for delivery contracts; in practice not applied to delivery contracts, rendering related form terms obsolete.
concepts.unlisted_description: Settlement days for contracts through Clearing House

anchor.surface_text: By-law 141. Settlement rates.- 1  For the purpose of these settlements, settlement prices for all positions of the Hedge Contract shall be fixed by the Board on or about the third working day immediately preceding Settlement Day.

concepts.interpretation: Provides for settlement rates based on hedge contracts with agreed allowances; no obligation to agree on difference if not done, blanks need not be filled if no agreement.

holdings.text: The contracts entered into between the appellants and the respondents were not void as alleged.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Substantial compliance with by-law 80's official form suffices per Privy Council precedent; specific omissions do not alter legal effect due to suspension of by-law 101 and obsolescence of settlement terms.

holdings.text: The expression 'not in accordance with' the by-laws requires only substantial compliance with the prescribed form, not literal compliance.

anchor.surface_text: The expression not in accordance with has been the subject of judicial interpretation in Radhakisson Gopikisson v. Balmukund Ramchandra  1 . Their Lordships of the Privy Council there held that the form prescribed was not a stereotyped one and that literal compliance with it was not essential.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Privy Council in Radhakisson Gopikisson v. Balmukund Ramchandra holding form not stereotyped; literal compliance not essential if all essential terms present.

holdings.text: Omission to mention measurements in the contract notes did not render the contracts not in accordance with the by-laws.
holdings.reasoning_summary: By-law 101 suspended Nov 30, 1942; no operational by-law requiring mention; by-laws 96/119 amended for rope-bound bales; trade practice accounted for; no change in legal effect.

holdings.text: Omission to fill in blanks regarding difference above or below settlement rate did not render contracts void.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No obligation to agree on difference (nil equivalent if no agreement); term obsolete as delivery contracts never through periodical settlements (by-laws 139/141 tacitly suspended); substantial compliance.

holdings.text: Appellants not entitled to recover Rs. 1,80,099-8-0 or any part thereof from respondents.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Contracts valid under s.8 Bombay Cotton Contracts Act; payments made as beneficiary under valid contracts; no basis for repayment.
